SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: CECIL SEED

Present Address: 1409 KETALLACK ST

Pioneer Address: TRECAHWA

Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1886

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's houses? Some

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? A week or Sunday

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Sundays

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Just went when convenient

What time of the day did you go, in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Afternoon or evening

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? In those days we were always welcome

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) Come and get it

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? Tea milk cake

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? Mostly one stayed to milk cows or tame

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Yes

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred. For building log house (one for each corner)

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe. Just just the first year but soon after

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. Yes started 1894

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? No just when the spirit moved

How many children of school age were there in the school?

How many children of school age were there in the school?

How many bachelors or others in the district helped in establishing the school? Explain.

Was there any opposition within the community towards the idea of starting a school? Explain.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? Remember the brass and the mutton skin hat, much dry ostrich feather.

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? Yes, but not practiced for some years. Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc. They came after my wedding, but it was so below outside, and often firing a few shots, came in side and was treated to apple.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? Yes

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization. It was started to get better prices as we used to go together and buy in quantity.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it? All

How many women belonged? All How often did it meet? 1 a month

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization? Mostly to buy goods in bulk.

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? No

When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (This is not in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

There was the grain growers and one before that I think it was called the grange. Royal temperance, and later Sack farmers union.

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money? Pass the hat.

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings? In community hall.

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? No

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them. They were used for political meetings when there was an election coming up.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? No Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

   Blind man's buff, and here we go round the mulberry bush.

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain. No only the children generally.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain. Lots of time in winter.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible. In July 1888.

26. Who organized it? Neighbors.

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? For everybody having their lunch and a little more for any stray one that might happen along.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? I don't know.

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? No band.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups? All ate at a long table in the grounds in the shade.

31. What did you have to eat and drink? Tea bread cake.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? Ten a.m. till about 7 o'clock p.m.

Some families used to go Sunday evening to valley play ball a while then go home

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

I don't be at any any more

Baseball, lacrosse
